author: Fred Thomas III, LA Mortgage Examiner
title: Mortgage rates take another dip
text:
Mortgage rates take another dip Use your key for the next article Home Sales are up, mortgage rates take another dive Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images 
Amid reports the Federal Reserve (Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System) was going to increase rates at its upcoming September meeting, attitudes have tempered and it appears nothing will change. The result is mortgage rates took another dip as reported by the weekly rate survey published by industry secondary giant Freddie Mac (Federal National Home Loan Mortgage Corporation). The benchmark 30 year mortgage dropped nearly 10 basis points in week over week reporting to wind up at 3.840% . That rate hasn’t been seen in nearly three months. 
The Fed’s decision 
Many had factored in China’s money woes as the reason on why the Fe d would increase rates and the impact would be higher cost to consumers for durable goods as well as mortgage loans. Wall Street took notice and rates plunged across the board. However the last couple of trading days have given hope as the market has recovered while posting some above market increases. 
The Fed’s decision as well as home sales data which shows buyers snapping up properties at impressive levels which point to the real estate industry is experiencing a seller’s market. The core question for many is how low will rates continue to drop? In the mortgage game that is always the unknown because at a moment’s notice rates will turn. For buyers of would be properties the decision they are weighing is making a bottom-line affordability decision. If they continue to wait, how much higher will properties rise, or how more difficult will it be for them to grab the property within their defined budget? 
"Events in China generated eye-catching volatility in equity markets worldwide over the past week. Interest rates also rocked up and down -- although to a lesser extent than equities -- as investors alternated between flights to quality and bargain hunting among beaten-down stocks. Amidst all this confusion, the 30-year mortgage rate dropped to 3.84 percent, the lowest mark since May and the fifth consecutive week with a rate below 4 percent." Sean Becketti, Chief Economist, Freddie Mac 
The 10 basis points drop for the 30 year mortgage is within typical range movement. The 15 year mortgage dropped to 3.060% and adjustable rate mortgages are as low as 2.620%. 
The rate survey is published weekly by Freddie Mac. The data is comprised from its nationwide network of approved lenders.
